title: How Sleep Transformed Professional Football
task_instruction: Read a text about how sleep transformed professional football, and for questions 1 to 6, choose the correct answer.

passages.title: The Sleep Revolution in Football
passages.text: A few decades ago, professional footballers spent their nights partying. Now, they are much more aware of the benefits of a good night's sleep. The change began in the mid-1990s, when mattress salesman Nick Littlehales contacted the manager of the Manchester United football team, Alex Ferguson, asking whether he had ever considered how sleep affected performance on the pitch.

passages.title: Early Adoption by Top Teams
passages.text: Interested, Ferguson arranged for Littlehales to give a presentation to his team. Before long, the whole team had new mattresses and pillows, and Littlehales soon became football's leading mattress advisor. In 1998, he supplied mattresses for England's World Cup team, and at the 2004 Euros, he created individual sleep routines for every player.

passages.title: Scientific Evidence for Sleep Benefits
passages.text: Gradually, club managers began to pay more attention to scientific sleep research, and for good reason. In 2011, sleep specialist Cheri Mah discovered that increasing sleep to 8-10 hours per night massively increased the speed and shot accuracy of basketball players. Other research shows that a single night of inadequate sleep can increase the risk of injury, and 64 hours of bad sleep reduces strength, power and balance, and can even cause the body to eat its own muscles!

passages.title: Practical Applications by Clubs
passages.text: Consequently, managers started trying to improve their players' sleep. Southampton Football Club's manager Alek Gross, for example, forbade his players from consuming caffeine, sugar or fatty foods, which prevent sleep, in the evenings. Instead, they were given milky protein drinks which made them tired. The Mexico team manager was also concerned about sleep loss when travelling to their World Cup group games in Russia. Together with Manchester United sports scientist Robin Thorpe, he drew up a sleep and training schedule to optimize performance.

passages.title: Player Commitment to Sleep Routines
passages.text: Even the hotel bedrooms were set to the ideal sleeping temperature. The players supported the routine. In fact, on the evening of a game, their captain Rafael Marquez even asked fans who were celebrating at the same hotel to keep quiet because the team were sleeping. The intervention was a great success. Mexico won their next game versus South Korea and even beat Germany in their group.

passages.title: Individualized Sleep Solutions
passages.text: Now, many teams and players are making an effort to improve their sleep patterns, using various means. Manchester City player Sergio Aguero, for example, was finding it hard to sleep because his muscular body prevented his legs from closing when he lay on his side. He got a new mattress which matched his height and weight, thus keeping his neck and back aligned in the night.

passages.title: Sleep Solutions for Different Needs
passages.text: Meanwhile, James Milner from Manchester City found it hard to sleep after evening games, so would play computer games into the early hours. As a result, he was too tired to train the following morning. Setting a routine with a late bedtime, early rise and afternoon nap helped to fix this problem. Since these interventions are cheap and effective, even the less well-known teams can benefit.

passages.title: Accessible Technology for All Teams
passages.text: Brentford, for example, has the smallest budget in the championship league. Even so, the club's head of performance, Chris Haslam, introduced wrist trackers to monitor player's sleep, and these have led to a clear improvement in players' attentiveness. Whereas in the past, playing after a party and a few hours' sleep was seen as a badge of honour, a good sleep is now considered an essential part of performance.

questions.question: What started the change in footballers' sleep habits?
options: A scientific study about sleep and performance
A mattress salesman contacting Alex Ferguson
Players complaining about tiredness
New rules about player rest periods
questions.answer: A mattress salesman contacting Alex Ferguson

questions.question: What did Cheri Mah's research show?
options: Sleep has no effect on athletic performance
More sleep improves speed and accuracy
Footballers need less sleep than other athletes
Sleep only affects mental performance
questions.answer: More sleep improves speed and accuracy

questions.question: What did Southampton FC change about their players' evening routine?
options: They introduced earlier bedtimes
They replaced unhealthy foods with sleep-inducing drinks
They made players sleep in special chambers
They banned all evening activities
questions.answer: They replaced unhealthy foods with sleep-inducing drinks

questions.question: How did Mexico's team show their commitment to sleep routines?
options: By traveling with their own mattresses
By asking fans to be quiet so they could sleep
By refusing to play evening games
By sleeping in special tents
questions.answer: By asking fans to be quiet so they could sleep

questions.question: What problem did Sergio Aguero have with sleep?
options: His muscular body made side-sleeping difficult
He suffered from insomnia
He preferred to sleep very little
His mattress was too soft
questions.answer: His muscular body made side-sleeping difficult

questions.question: How did Brentford improve their players' sleep on a small budget?
options: By using wrist trackers to monitor sleep
By buying expensive mattresses
By hiring sleep specialists
By building a special sleep center
questions.answer: By using wrist trackers to monitor sleep
